The Dharma of leaving the household life cannot be destroyed. If one seeks good teachings, there is nothing superior to the Buddha's teachings.
It is like a hundred blind people, and there is a skilled doctor who can cure their eyes, enabling them to see clearly all at once.
There are also a hundred people whose eyes should be gouged out as punishment, and there is one powerful person who can save them from their crime and prevent them from losing their eyes.

Although the blessings of these two people are immeasurable, they are still not as great as allowing others to leave the household life and leaving the household life oneself, whose blessings are vast.
Why is this?
Although one may give eyes to two kinds of people, these people only gain benefits for one lifetime each, and moreover, the nature of the flesh eyes is perishable;

If one allows others to go forth, or if one goes forth oneself, one will gradually guide sentient beings to the unsurpassed wisdom eye for eternal kalpas, and the nature of the wisdom eye is indestructible throughout kalpas.
Why is this?
The rewards of blessings in the human and heavenly realms, indulging in pleasures, are inexhaustible, and one will eventually attain Buddhahood.
Why is this?

Because the Dharma of going forth destroys the retinue of Mara, increases the Buddha lineage, crushes evil dharmas, nurtures good dharmas, eliminates sinful defilements, and promotes the unsurpassed meritorious deeds. Therefore, the Buddha said that the merit of going forth is higher than Mount Sumeru, deeper than the great ocean, and vaster than space.

If someone creates obstacles for those who have left the household life, preventing them from fulfilling their aspirations, their offense is extremely grave, like the pitch-black darkness of night where nothing can be seen. The karmic retribution for this person will also be like this, entering the deep darkness of hell without eyes.
It is like the great ocean, into which all the hundreds of rivers and streams flow. The karmic retribution for this person will also be like this, with all evil things gathering in their body.
It is like Mount Sumeru being burned by the conflagration at the end of the eon, leaving no trace. This person will also be like this, burned by the fires of hell without end.
It is like the extremely poisonous and bitter medicine called Kaliyuga, which, in terms of weight, is comparable to molasses. The karmic retribution for good and evil is also like this.

If one allows others to go forth or goes forth oneself, the merit is greatest. Because those who have gone forth use the sutras as water to wash away the defilements of afflictions, they can eliminate the suffering of birth and death and become the cause for nirvana;

They use the Vinaya as feet to tread on the ground of pure precepts, and the Abhidharma as eyes to see the good and evil in the world. They can roam freely on the path of the eightfold right path and reach the wonderful city of nirvana.
For this reason, if one allows others to go forth or goes forth oneself, whether old or young, the merit is supreme.
At that time, the World-Honored One was staying in the Kalandaka Bamboo Grove in RÄjagá¹›ha.

At that time, in RÄjagá¹›ha there was an elder named ÅšrÄ«vatsa (meaning increasing blessings), who was a hundred years old. Hearing that the merit of going forth was immeasurable like this, he thought to himself:

He then said goodbye to his wife, children, slaves, and all the family members:ğŸ”½I wish to go forth and cultivate the path in the Buddha's teachings.
I wish to go forth.
The people in his household, young and old, all despised him, and no one would follow his words or listen to him. When they heard he wanted to go forth, they all said happily:
You should have left earlier, why wait until now?
Now is the right time.

After arriving at the Bamboo Grove, he asked the monks:

The monks replied:
The TathÄgata, the World-Honored One, is currently traveling elsewhere to teach and benefit, he is not here.

He then went to where ÅšÄriputra was, put down his staff, bowed, and said:
Venerable One!

At that time, ÅšÄriputra, having looked at this person, thought that he was old and lacked in the three abilities [of study, meditation, and service], and said:
Go away, your old age is past, you cannot go forth.
Next, he went to MahÄkÄÅ›yapa, UpÄli, Aniruddha, and the other five hundred great arhats, and they all asked:
Have you already gone to the others?
He replied:
I have already gone to the World-Honored One, but the World-Honored One was not there, so next I went to the Venerable ÅšÄriputra.
They also asked:
What did he say?
He replied:
He told me:
'Your old age is past, you cannot go forth.'
The bhiká¹£us said:
Even Shariputra, who is foremost in wisdom, does not allow you, and we also do not allow you.
It is like a skilled doctor who knows how to treat illnesses but abandons them without curing them, and other lesser doctors also fold their hands. You should know that this person will surely die.
Because Shariputra, with his great wisdom, did not allow it, the other bhikshus also did not allow it.
Shiribifuti, seeking the bhikshus, was unable to go forth and leave the Bamboo Grove. He stayed at the gate, crying sadly and wailing loudly:
Since my birth, I have not had any great faults. Why do you specifically not allow me to go forth?ğŸ”½Like Upali, a lowly barber;
Niti, a lowly and filthy sweeper of excrement;
Angulimala, who killed countless people;
And Dhataraá¹­á¹­ha, a great thief and evil person;
Such people are still allowed to go forth, what crime have I committed that I am not allowed to go forth?

When he said this, the World-Honored One suddenly appeared before him, emitting a great radiance, adorned with the marks and characteristics, like the seven treasures and tall carriage of the king of the Heaven of the Thirty-three Celestials.
The Buddha asked Bhadrika:
Why are you crying?

At that time, the elder heard the Buddha's Brahma-like voice, and his heart was filled with joy, like a child seeing his father. He prostrated with his whole body and made offerings to the Buddha, weeping and saying to the Buddha:
All sentient beings, even murderers, thieves, liars, and slanderers, even those of low caste, are all allowed to go forth;
Why is it that I alone, with what crime, am specifically not allowed to go forth in the Buddha's teachings?
In my family, both young and old, because of my old age and senility, no longer employ me.
Now, if I am not allowed to go forth in the Buddha's teachings;
If I now return home, they will certainly not accept me. Where else can I go?
I will now definitely give up my life here.
At that time, the Buddha told ÅšrÄ« BharadvÄja:

The elder said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
The Dharma-cakra-turning king, the foremost wise son, next to the Buddha, the second world guide, ÅšÄriputra, he does not allow me to go forth in the Buddha's Dharma.
At that time, the World-Honored One!
With great compassion, he comforted Puá¹‡á¹‡ika, just as a kind father comforts his filial son, and said to him:

It is not because ÅšÄriputra has diligently practiced for three asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas and cultivated merit for a hundred kalpas;

It is not because ÅšÄriputra has practiced austerities in life after life, breaking his head, gouging out his eyes, giving away his marrow, brain, blood, flesh, skin, bones, hands, feet, ears, and nose;

It is not because ÅšÄriputra has mastery over the Dharma, so how can he say:
'This one should leave home, this one should not.'

Only I, alone, ride the jeweled chariot of the six pÄramitÄs, clad in the armor of forbearance, sitting under the bodhi tree on the adamantine seat, subduing the demon king and his foes, alone attaining Buddhahood, with none equal to me.

The World-Honored One comforted him in various ways, and his grief was immediately dispelled. With a greatly joyful mind, he followed the Buddha into the Buddha's monastery and told MahÄmaudgalyÄyana:

Why is it so?

This person has already planted the causes and conditions for liberation in past lives. By swallowing the hook of the Dharma, like a fish swallowing a hook, there is no doubt that they will emerge. Because of their old age, they are unable to respectfully welcome and send off the elders in a timely manner. The younger monks, because they went forth earlier, are elders. They always bitterly and harshly reprimand:

At that time, the old monk then thinks to themselves:

They also think like this:

At that time, by the side of the forest, there was a large river with deep and swift water. He went to the bank, took off his monk's robe, placed it on a tree branch, knelt for a long time facing the robe, wept with tears streaming down, and made a vow:

I now do not abandon the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹ƒgha, but only wish to give up my life. If there are people in the world who are wise and discerning, and have a genuine and upright nature, the gods should respect them. If there are those who are wise but harbor flattery and deception, they can be teachers for people, and people should respect and make offerings to them.

He then said to his teacher:

On the shore, there was a newly dead woman, with a beautiful face and a wonderful body, endowed with all the excellent characteristics. 'If there are sentient beings who steal the wealth of the Three Jewels and their parents' possessions, up to killing people, such great offenses should cause them to fall into the blazing fire hell.
